problem.tex: Let $p$ be a polynomial of degree $d\geq2$ with distinct roots $a_i$. Show \[\sum_{i=1}^d\frac{1}{p'(a_i)}=0.\]

solution.tex:
First, are we dividing by zero? How do we know that $p'(a_i)
eq0$ for all $i$? This is because the roots are distinct. If $p'(a)=0$ then $a$ is a root of order at least 2, so it is not a distinct root. Therefore $p'(a_i)
eq0$ for all $i$. Moreover, note $p$ takes the form \[p(z)=\lambda\prod_{i=1}^n(z-a_i)\] by the fundamental theorem of algebra. Now to answer the question. Let $R>0$ be large enough that all $|a_i|<R$ and let $\gamma(t)=Re^{it}$. Consider the integral \[\int_\gamma\prod_{i=1}^n rac{1}{z-a_i}dz.\] Fix any $i$ and use Cauchy's integral formula for the curve $\gamma_i$ which encircles only the pole at $a_i$. \[\int_{\gamma_i} rac{\prod_{j
eq i} rac{1}{z-a_j}}{z-a_i}dz=(2\pi i)\prod_{j
eq i} rac{1}{a_i-a_j}=(2\pi i) rac{\lambda}{p'(a_i)}\] The last equality comes from the multi-chain-rule computation of $p'$, plugging in $a_i$ cancels most of the terms. Therefore \[\int_\gamma\prod_{i=1}^n rac{1}{z-a_i}dz=(2\pi i)\sum_{i=1}^n rac{\lambda}{p'(a_i)}.\] Alternately, let $d$ be the degree of $p$. Then $|\prod_{i=1}^n(z-a_i)|\sim R^d$ as $|z|$ gets very large. Then the integral is \[\left|\int_\gamma\prod_{i=1}^n rac{1}{z-a_i}dzight|\sim\left|\int_\gamma rac{1}{R^d}dzight|\leq2\pi rac{1}{R^{d-1}}	o0.\] The limit goes to 0 because $d\geq2$. That shows our result.
